JSON::value

JSON::value Class Reference

This class represents any JSON value. A value can have any of the basic JSON datatypes, as defined in datatype::dt. internal data management is handled automatically, along with character encoding conversion between UTF-8 and Unicode. More...

#include <value.h>

Static Public Attributes

static value nullval
 Used by any function that should return a reference to a value but may not be able to, for example in search functions. It is a major hack, but to test for a valid response from these functions, compare the address of the returned reference to this variable.

Private Attributes

datatype::dt dt
dataptr val

Detailed Description

This class represents any JSON value. A value can have any of the basic JSON datatypes, as defined in datatype::dt. internal data management is handled automatically, along with character encoding conversion between UTF-8 and Unicode.

Because of the nature of the JSON specification, only one class is needed to represent all datatypes. For example, a valid JSON file can be expressed as a single JSON 'object'.

bool value::setarray ( const raw_array_t &  newval  ) 

Sets this value to a JSON Array, and clones newval by recursively copying it's members.

Returns:
true
Any previous values are deleted

bool value::setarray ( raw_array_t *  newval  ) 

THIS METHOD IS DANGEROUS.

Returns:
true
The value is set directly to the raw JSON Array pointed to by newval. If newval is owned by another JSON value, then you will get double frees AND YOUR PROGRAM WILL CRASH. This value will delete newval when it finishes with it. This should only be used for optimisation purposes, and very carefully.

Any previous values are deleted This method is only available if JSON_UNSAFE_FUNS is defined at compile-time

bool value::setobject ( raw_object_t *  newval  ) 

THIS METHOD IS DANGEROUS.

Returns:
true
The value is set directly to the raw JSON Object pointed to by newval. If newval is owned by another value, then you will get double frees AND YOUR PROGRAM WILL CRASH. This value will delete newval when it finishes with it. This should only be used for optimisation purposes, and very carefully.

Any previous values are deleted This method is only available if JSON_UNSAFE_FUNS is defined at compile-time

bool value::addvalue ( value *  newval  ) 

THIS METHOD IS DANGEROUS.

Returns:
true if the value was added successfully. false if this is not a JSON array.
newval is appended directly onto this array. If newval is owned by another JSON value, then you will get double frees AND YOUR PROGRAM WILL CRASH. This value will delete newval when it finishes with it.

This should only be used for optimisation purposes, and very carefully.

Any previous values are deleted This method is only available if JSON_UNSAFE_FUNS is defined at compile-time

bool value::addvalue ( const char *  newname,
value *  newval 
)

THIS METHOD IS DANGEROUS.

Returns:
true if the value was added successfully. false if this is not a JSON object.
newval is added directly into this JSON object, using newname as a key. A copy of newname will be converted into the correct character encoding if neccessary If newval is owned by another JSON value, then you will get double frees AND YOUR PROGRAM WILL CRASH. This value will delete newval when it finishes with it.

This should only be used for optimisation purposes, and very carefully.

Any previous values are deleted This method is only available if JSON_UNSAFE_FUNS is defined at compile-time

bool value::deletechild ( value *  dval  ) 

Looks to see if this value [must be array or object] contains the value pointed to by val. If it does, then dval is removed from the list and deleted.

Returns:
true if the child value is found and deleted false if the child value is not found

bool value::deletechild ( const wchar_t *  name  ) 

Searches this value [must be a JSON object] for a child value with name name. If found, the child is deleted and removed from the container. Automatic Utf-8 <-> Unicode conversion is done where neccessary.

Returns:
true if the child value is found and deleted false if the child value is not found

bool value::deletechild ( const char *  name  ) 

Searches this value [must be a JSON object] for a child value with name name. If found, the child is deleted and removed from the list. Automatic Utf-8 <-> Unicode conversion is done where neccessary.

Returns:
true if the child value is found and deleted false if the child value is not found

value & value::getchild ( const wchar_t *  name  ) 

shallow searches for a child value whose name matches name. this must be a JSON object

If no such child value is found, a new value is created with the specified name, and returned instead.

Returns:
A reference to the child value. WARNING, if this, is deleted, or this[name] is deleted, then the reference will become invalid.
We do not do reference counting here.

value & value::getchild ( const char *  name  ) 

shallow searches for a child value whose name matches name. this must be a JSON object

If no such child value is found, a new value is created with the specified name, and returned instead.

Returns:
A reference to the child value. WARNING, if this, is deleted, or this[name] is deleted, then the reference will become invalid.
We do not do reference counting here.

bool value::getbool ( bool  _default = false  ) 

returns a bool representing the current value of this

Returns:
returns a bool representing the current value of this
Reasonable attempts will be made to cast the current value into a bool, using the following rules:

type is a literal : true if the value is true, otherwise false.

type is an array or object : true if the array contains members > 0, otherwise false.

type is a Number : true if the number != 0, otherwise false.

type is a string: true if the length > 0, otherwise false.

type is undefined : returns value of _default

JSON::literals::literals value::getliteral ( JSON::literals::literals  _default = literals::_null  ) 

returns a literals::literals representing the current value of this

Returns:
returns the current value if the dataype is literal. Otherwise returns _default

aint value::getinteger ( aint  _default = 0  ) 

returns an integer representing the current value of this

Returns:
returns an integer representing the current value of this.
If datatype is fixed_number (integer), then the value is returned

If datatype is number (float), then the return is cast to integer.

Otherwise, the _default value is returned.

afloat value::getfloat ( afloat  _default = 0  ) 

returns a float representing the current value of this

Returns:
returns a float representing the current value of this.
If datatype is fixed_number (integer), then the value is returned

If datatype is number (float), then the value is returned.

Otherwise, the _default value is returned.

std::wstring & value::getstring ( std::wstring &  dest,
bool  enquote = false,
bool  newline = false 
)

fills dest with the string representation of the current value of this

If datatype is fixed_number (integer), or number (float), then dst will contain a string representation of the number, similar to itoa or gcvt.

If datatype is string, then dst will contain the string.

If datatype is literal, then dst will contain one of: L"true",L"false" or L"null"

If datatype is array or object, then dst will contain valid JSON, while each child added recursively. [output is only valid JSON if enquote is true]

Parameters:
dest This will be filled with the return value
enquote If this is true, then strings and object names will be properly quoted and escaped. passing true here will guarantee valid JSON
newline If this is an object or array, then each child value will be output on a separate line.
Returns:
a reference to dest.

std::string & value::getstring ( std::string &  dest,
bool  enquote = false,
bool  newline = false 
)

raw_array_t & value::getrawarray (  ) 

raw_object_t & value::getrawobject (  ) 

bool value::clear (  ) 

Removes and deletes all child values of this array or object.

Returns:
true if the value has children that were deleted false if the value is of the wrong datatype

value & value::operator[] ( aint  index  ) 

returns a reference to the array child at index index.

If this[index] doesn't exist, then a new value is created and returned.

If datatype is not array, then a reference to JSON::value::nullval is returned. To detect this, compare a pointer the returned reference to a pointer to value::nullval

Returns:
A reference to the index index of the JSON array. Or a reference to value::nullval if the dataype is wrong.

value & value::operator[] ( const wchar_t *  name  ) 

returns a reference to the object child with name name

If this[name] doesn't exist, then a new value is created and returned.

If datatype is not array, then a reference to JSON::value::nullval is returned. To detect this, compare a pointer the returned reference to a pointer to value::nullval

Returns:
A reference to the name index of the JSON object. Or a reference to value::nullval if the dataype is wrong.

value & value::operator[] ( const char *  name  ) 

returns a reference to the object child with name name

If this[name] doesn't exist, then a new value is created and returned.

If datatype is not array, then a reference to JSON::value::nullval is returned. To detect this, compare a pointer the returned reference to a pointer to value::nullval

Returns:
A reference to the name index of the JSON object. Or a reference to value::nullval if the dataype is wrong.

Deletes the data held in this value,(same as setting the datatype to undefined).

Returns:
true if the value was set to undefined.

bool value::clone ( const value &  oldval  ) 

Sets this value to be an exact copy of the data in another value. Recursively copying arrays and objects.

Returns:
true if the copy succeeds, false if an unknown error occurred (i.e. data corruption)

Member Data Documentation

datatype::dt JSON::value::dt [private]

dataptr JSON::value::val [private]

value value::nullval [static]

Used by any function that should return a reference to a value but may not be able to, for example in search functions. It is a major hack, but to test for a valid response from these functions, compare the address of the returned reference to this variable.
